education.area: Specialist Program in Computer Science, Major in Statistics

work.name: Freelance
highlights: Integrated, containerized, and fine-tuned PHP-based CRM system for a major critical infrastructure company, resulting in 23% decrease in maintenance costs, and reduced time spent on repetitive tasks by 30 minutes per day.
Cleaned up the database with SQL and migrated it to MariaDB, making it ~50x smaller with no data losses.
Wrote Bash and Python scripts to automate the administration and backup of the data, helping to reduce backup costs and recovery costs by 70%.

Created solutions for monitoring and troubleshooting critical industry systems using Arduino-based microcontrollers, resulting in average savings of $1300 per false-positive, and preventing production lines closures.

Collaborated with all top Canadian universities, and industry leaders to orchestrate nationwide DevFest events, and hosted workshops on prompt engineering during the events with over 600 students just at the University of Toronto.

Hosted five-week ML Study Jams, teaching TensorFlow, Pandas, and Seaborn to introduce Machine Learning, and Deep Learning concepts to students, resulting in high attendance and highly positive feedback, with my students winning Kaggle competitions, hackathons, and datathons.

Helped the speakers throughout their talks at 2 days long Women in Tech Conference at Microsoft HQ, for 180+ participants, featuring 25+ workshops, panels, and speeches to celebrate the achievements of women in technology.

activities.summary: Managed the judging process, ensured on-time assessment of the projects, and handled prizes at Largest AI hackathon in Canada with 1200+ registrations, 250+ hackers from 11 countries, 15 mentors, 30 judges, 66 projects.

projects.name: Quantum Computing
projects.summary: Quantum computing is the use of quantum-mechanical phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform computation. Computers that perform quantum computations are known as quantum computers.

awards.title: Nobel Prize in Physics
awards.summary: The Nobel Prizes are five separate prizes that, according to Alfred Nobel's will of 1895, are awarded to 'those who, during the preceding year, have conferred the greatest benefit to humankind.'
